title: AB 250
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 2290.5 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define terms related to telemedicine, including "asynchronous store and forward" and "synchronous interaction." This division applies to health care providers licensed under the code, including marriage and family therapist interns. Telehealth is defined as delivering healthcare services via technology to facilitate diagnosis, treatment, and patient education. Prior to using telehealth, providers must inform and obtain consent from patients. Prior to delivering healthcare via telehealth, providers must inform patients and obtain consent for using telehealth as a mode of healthcare delivery. Failure to comply with this requirement is considered unprofessional conduct. Telehealth interactions are subject to laws regarding confidentiality of healthcare information and patient rights to medical information. (e) This section does not change the scope of practice for healthcare providers or allow the delivery of healthcare services in unauthorized settings. Laws on patient confidentiality and rights to medical information apply to telehealth. This section does not apply to patients in correctional facilities. Hospitals can grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers based on recommendations from their medical staff. The Legislature intends to authorize hospitals to grant privileges and verify credentials for telehealth providers. Telehealth includes telemedicine as defined in federal regulations. Applicants for licensure must complete 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks, with specific requirements for supervised hours. Applicants for licensure must complete 3,000 hours of experience over 104 weeks, with specific requirements for supervised hours. Not more than 1,300 hours of supervised experience can be obtained before completing a master’s or doctoral degree, with restrictions on counseling and direct supervisor contact hours. No experience can be gained before completing 12 semester units or 18 quarter units of graduate instruction, except for personal psychotherapy. Hours of experience cannot be gained more than six years prior to filing the application for examination eligibility, except for up to 500 hours of clinical experience gained in supervised practicum. A combined total of 1,000 hours of experience is allowed for direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities. Not more than 1,000 hours of experience allowed for direct supervisor contact and professional enrichment activities, including workshops, seminars, training sessions, conferences, and personal psychotherapy. Additionally, not more than 500 hours of experience providing group therapy or counseling, and not more than 500 hours of experience gained after January 1, 2012. For hours gained on or after January 1, 2012, the applicant must have experience in administering psychological tests, client advocacy, diagnosing and treating couples, families, and children, and providing personal psychotherapy via telehealth. It is encouraged to work with elders and dependent adults with limitations. Applicants, trainees, and registrants must gain supervised experience working with elders and dependent adults with limitations. Supervision ensures counseling aligns with training and laws. Experience must be gained as an employee or volunteer, not as an independent contractor. Interns must provide W-2 tax forms for each year of experience claimed. Interns must provide W-2 tax forms or a letter from their employer verifying volunteer work when applying for licensure. Supervision requirements include one hour of direct supervisor contact for every five hours of client contact, with additional supervision for those with more than 10 hours of client contact in a week. An individual supervised after obtaining a qualifying degree must have one additional hour of direct supervisor contact for every week with more than 10 hours of client contact. No more than six hours of supervision can be credited in a single week. Direct supervisor contact can be face-to-face on an individual basis or in a group of up to eight supervisees for at least one continuous hour. Interns in specific settings can use real-time videoconferencing for weekly supervisor contact. (6) Interns in certain settings can use real-time videoconferencing for weekly supervisor contact to ensure client confidentiality. (7) Supervisors must monitor all experience gained by trainees as per regulations. (8) Trainees can receive up to six hours of credited supervision per week starting from January 1, 2009. (d) (1) Trainees can receive credit for supervised experience in settings that lawfully provide mental health counseling and meet supervision requirements. Trainees and interns can gain supervised experience in settings that provide mental health counseling or psychotherapy, with oversight to ensure work meets requirements and is within the scope of practice. The setting cannot be a private practice owned by certain licensed professionals. An intern must receive oversight to ensure their work meets requirements and is within the scope of practice for mental health counseling or psychotherapy. They cannot work in a private practice until registered, but fair remuneration is encouraged. Direct supervision by a licensed professional is required in a private practice setting, with alternative arrangements allowed during supervisor absences. To gain experience for licensure, interns must register with the board and apply within 90 days of receiving their qualifying degree. They cannot receive payment from patients and must be paid by their employers. Trainees, interns, and applicants must only be paid by their employers and cannot receive remuneration from patients. They are required to perform services under the direction and control of their employer, including via telehealth, and must not have any proprietary interest in their employer's business. Trainees, interns, or applicants receiving up to $500 per month for expenses in lawful work settings are considered employees, not independent contractors. Applicants may be audited to prove expenses were incurred. Each educational institution and supervisor should consider encouraging students, interns, and trainees to undergo counseling or psychotherapy as appropriate. Assistance in locating affordable counseling services should be provided if desired by the applicant.
